questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <1

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of small pre-antral follicles. It serves as a marker for ovarian reserve, reflecting the remaining egg supply in the ovaries.

 

  • AMH in Low Ovarian Reserve: In cases of low ovarian reserve, the AMH level will be less than 1 ng/mL. This indicates a diminished number of remaining follicles and a reduced capacity for fertility.
  • AMH in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS typically have increased levels of AMH due to the presence of a higher number of small antral follicles.

 

Tests for Ovarian Reserve

 

  1. Biochemical Tests:
    • FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone): Levels measured on Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Estradiol: Day 2 levels are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Inhibin B: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
    • AMH: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Antral Follicle Count (AFC): Done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total number of visible follicles are counted. An AFC greater than 10 is considered normal.
  3. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test: This test evaluates ovarian reserve by measuring FSH levels before and after administration of clomiphene citrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-4: Levels of AMH within this range might be seen in women with a moderate ovarian reserve. It is not indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. >7: High levels of AMH are often associated with PCOS, where there is an increased number of small antral follicles.

 

Option D. >10: Extremely high AMH levels are usually seen in conditions like PCOS and do not indicate low ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) levels less than 1 ng/mL are indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Page 437, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Cannon ball metastases on chest X-ray are seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choriocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Cannonball metastases refer to multiple, round, well-circumscribed nodules seen on a chest X-ray, typically representing metastatic deposits. These are characteristic of hematogenous spread to the lungs.

 

 

Choriocarcinoma:

 

Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant trophoblastic tumor that often follows a molar pregnancy but can also arise after a normal pregnancy or abortion.

 

It is known for its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, particularly to the lungs, where it can cause cannonball metastases.

 

Despite its aggressive nature, choriocarcinoma responds well to chemotherapy, and lung metastases are associated with a relatively good prognosis compared to other metastatic sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete mole: This refers to a hydatidiform mole, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease, which may precede choriocarcinoma but does not directly present with cannonball metastases.

 

Option C. Invasive mole: This is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that invades the myometrium but typically does not present with cannonball metastases in the lungs.

 

Option D. Partial mole: This is a type of molar pregnancy with less malignant potential than a complete mole and does not present with cannonball metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannonball metastases on a chest X-ray are a hallmark of choriocarcinoma, representing lung metastases that, despite indicating spread, are associated with a good prognosis due to the tumor's sensitivity to chemotherapy.

questions.text:
Which muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Duttaâ€™s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

 

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is a technique commonly used for the detection of autoantibodies. It involves applying the patient's serum to a substrate that expresses the antigen(s) of interest. If autoantibodies are present, they bind to these antigens. Then another anti-human antibody is added to amplify the response generated. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Immunofluorescence: Used for tissue-bound antibodies where the patient's tissues are stained directly to detect deposits of immunoglobulins or complement.

 

Option B. ELISA: Mainly used for quantifying serum levels of specific antibodies against predefined antigens.

 

Option D. FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization): Used for identifying chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations rather than detecting antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect immunofluorescence allows for the detection of circulating autoantibodies in patient serum by using antigen-expressing substrates, making it a critical tool for diagnosing various autoimmune diseases.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cell

 

The marked cell is Mast cell which is stained deep blue with Toluidine blue.

 

 

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and these cells are responsible for the allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

 

When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulation occurs releasing various mediators like Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin, Lipid mediators (Leukotriene C4, D4), prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor cytokines (TNF, IL 1).

questions.text: Bowing of legs with bleeding gums is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

 

Bowing of legs can be mistakenly attributed to vitamin D deficiency, which typically causes rickets in children.

 

However, the presence of bleeding gums points specifically to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Vitamin C is crucial for collagen synthesis and other structural aspects of bone formation. This deficiency, known as scurvy, involves various skeletal changes including defective osteoid matrix formation and osteolysis, beyond just the commonly noted bleeding gums. The combined symptoms of bowing of legs and bleeding gums can indeed suggest a scenario where vitamin C deficiency plays a contributory role alongside other deficiencies like vitamin D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial tissues, not typically associated with bleeding gums or significant skeletal changes like bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Incorrect as Vitamin E deficiency generally leads to neurological problems and muscle weakness, not directly linked with bleeding gums or bone deformities.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Incorrect because while Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, its deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of legs; it would rather lead to bleeding issues without the skeletal deformities noted here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin C deficiency can cause bleeding gums and is associated with significant bone structure changes, leading to conditions like scurvy that may present with skeletal deformities such as bowing of legs.

questions.text: 15-year-old girl with wide-spaced nipples, short height, and the following karyotype: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome


Turner syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45, X) rather than the typical two sex chromosomes (XX or XY). The karyotype shown confirms the absence of the Y chromosome and only one X chromosome, which is diagnostic of Turner syndrome. Clinical features often include short stature, wide-spaced nipples, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. Turner syndrome is a common genetic condition tested in exams due to its distinctive features and significant clinical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It does not fit the description of a 15-year-old girl with the specific karyotype shown and is not associated with the physical characteristics described.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra chromosome 21) and typically presents with distinct facial features, intellectual disability, and other health issues. The karyotype shown does not match Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Partial mole: A partial mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease involving an abnormal pregnancy with an extra set of paternal chromosomes, often presenting with symptoms related to pregnancy and abnormal placental tissue rather than the clinical features described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45,X, and typical clinical features include short stature and wide-spaced nipples, commonly seen in females.

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to the hospital with blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nifedipine

 

Explanation

 

In managing hypertension in a pregnant patient with a history of bronchial asthma, the choice of antihypertensive medication is critical due to the contraindications of certain drug classes in both pregnancy and asthma.

 

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it the preferred choice for hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with asthma.

 

Nicardipine, another calcium channel blocker, can also be used, especially in IV form, but nifedipine is often chosen due to its safety profile and efficacy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Oral Labetalol and Option C. IV Labetalol: Contraindicated in asthma due to bronchoconstriction. These drugs can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction, making them unsuitable for patients with asthma.

 

Option D. Ramipril: ACE inhibitors like Ramipril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal toxicity, including renal damage and oligohydramnios

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with bronchial asthma, nifedipine is the preferred drug due to its safety in pregnancy and lack of bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining the anterior capsule of the lens?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trypan blue

 

Trypan blue dye is commonly used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery, specifically to facilitate the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis. This dye helps surgeons to visualize the capsule better, making the procedure safer and more precise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein green: This dye is used to stain corneal epithelial defects and is not used for staining the anterior lens capsule.

 

Option C. Brilliant blue: This dye is used in retinal surgeries to stain the internal limiting membrane (ILM), aiding in ILM peeling during macular hole surgeries. It is not used for lens capsule staining.

 

Option D. Rose Bengal: This dye stains dead or devitalized cells and is used in the diagnosis of conditions like dry eye syndrome. It is not used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypan blue dye is used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery to aid in the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis.

 

Various Dyes used in Opthalmology -

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isnâ€™t preferred as it doesnâ€™t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmiaâ€™s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The above picture is showing the structure of fungal cell wall most likely of Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Fungal cell wall components - The fungal cell wall contains a cell membrane with various membrane proteins, a protective layer of chitin (yellow) as well as glucans (mostly beta) and mannoproteins on its surface. Different fungal cell walls contain different glucans. For example, the cell wall of A. fumigatus contains Î²-1,3- and Î²-1,4-glucan, and Î±-1,3-glucan, while C. albicans contains Î²-1,3- and Î²-1,6-glucan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall structure has three major cell wall features, including peptidoglycan, arabinogalactan and mycolic acid.

 

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumonia is bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Cell wall is absent.

 

 

Option D. Recently, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been considered a fungus, but it was originally thought to be a protozoan parasite. Its morphologic characteristics resemble those of Coccidioides immitis: both organisms have mature stages that consist of large, thick-walled spherical structures containing smaller daughter cells (endospores). In addition, R. seeberi is visualized with fungal stains such as methenamine silver and periodic acid-Schiff, as well as mucicarmine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fungal cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus contains Î²-glucans, chitin, and mannoproteins.

choices.text: Switch to low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: A pregnant female at 37 weeks of gestation with a history of prosthetic heart valves is currently taking warfarin. She comes for a routine antenatal check-up. What is the appropriate management advice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Switch to low molecular weight heparin

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is commonly used in patients with prosthetic heart valves to prevent thromboembolic events. However, warfarin is known to cross the placenta and can cause fetal complications, particularly when used during the first trimester. It is also associated with an increased risk of bleeding during delivery if continued into the third trimester.

 

The standard management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves involves switching from warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as delivery approaches. LMWH is preferred during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester and after 36 weeks of gestation, due to its safety profile and because it does not cross the placenta.

 

In this case, at 37 weeks of gestation, it is important to switch from warfarin to LMWH to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during delivery and to avoid any adverse effects on the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate induction of labor: Induction of labor may be considered under specific conditions but is not the first-line management for anticoagulation issues.

 

Option B. Perform LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): A cesarean section might be necessary based on obstetric indications but is not related to the management of anticoagulation in this context.

 

Option C. Continue the same medication: Continuing warfarin at 37 weeks is not recommended due to the risks of bleeding during delivery and potential harm to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves:

 

1st Trimester â€“ LMWH

2nd Trimester â€“ LMWH >> Warfarin

3rd Trimester â€“  LMWH

Overall best option - LMWH

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have bilateral tubal block on HSG. The next best step is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy with chromotubation

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is often the first test used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes in women experiencing infertility. If the HSG reveals a bilateral tubal block, the next best step is to confirm the findings through laparoscopy with chromotubation. This procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the fallopian tubes. Chromotubation involves the injection of a dye through the fallopian tubes to assess their patency directly, which is more accurate than imaging alone. Additionally, if the block is confirmed, there may be an opportunity to address it surgically during the same procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVF: While IVF is a valid treatment option for tubal factor infertility, it is generally considered after confirming the tubal block with laparoscopy. IVF is often chosen if re-canalization attempts fail or if the patient prefers to bypass surgery.

 

Option C. IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): IUI is not suitable in cases of confirmed bilateral tubal block because it requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm to reach the egg.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Letrozole is an ovulation induction agent used in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It is not appropriate for treating tubal block issues and thus is not relevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After identifying a bilateral tubal block on HSG in a woman with primary infertility, the next best step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromotubation before considering other treatments like IVF.

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetic causes least myocardial depression and maximum hemodynamic stability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etomidate

 

  • Among the options given, Etomidate is unique in that it causes minimal cardiovascular depression.
  • This makes it particularly useful in patients with compromised cardiac function or hemodynamic instability
  • Etomidate is an imidazoline derivative used for IV anaesthesia induction, and it offers several advantages:
    • Low risk of myocardial depression
    • Hemodynamic stability on bolus injection

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. It also produces vasodilation which can further lower blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in cardiac output and blood pressure. It also has a vasodilatory effect which can further compromise hemodynamics.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Unlike most other anesthetics, Ketamine typically has a stimulatory effect on the cardiovascular system. It often increases heart rate and blood pressure due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects. However, in patients with depleted catecholamines or in certain pathological conditions, it might not exhibit this stimulatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol and Thiopentone are known to cause myocardial depression, Etomidate is recognized for its minimal cardiovascular depression, and Ketamine typically stimulates the cardiovascular system, but with certain exceptions.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A case of accidental burn injuries in a female patient aged 35 years involving right upper limb, entire right lower limb, entire front and back of abdomen. Which of the following is the percentage of burn injuries according to the rule of nine? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45%

 

The rule of nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. According to this rule, the body is divided into sections that represent approximately 9% (or multiples of 9%) of the TBSA.

 

  • Right upper limb: Each upper limb is 9% (4.5% for the front and 4.5% for the back).
  • Right lower limb: Each lower limb is 18% (9% for the front and 9% for the back).
  • Entire front and back of the abdomen: The anterior trunk (front) and the posterior trunk (back) together make up 18% (9% for the front and 9% for the back).

 

 

Calculating the total percentage of burn injuries:

 

  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right lower limb: 18%
  • Entire front and back of the abdomen: 18%

 

Therefore, the total percentage of burn injuries is:

 

9% (upper limb) + 18% (lower limb) + 18% (abdomen) = 45%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

choices.text: ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) â€“ Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

 

Explanation:

 

Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) occurs when there is involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining, coughing, sneezing, or exercising. This condition is often due to weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the urethral sphincter, which fail to properly support the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urge urinary incontinence: This type of incontinence is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by involuntary leakage of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence: This occurs when a person experiences symptoms of both stress and urge urinary incontinence.

 

Option D. Overflow incontinence: This type occurs when the bladder fails to empty completely, leading to leakage of small amounts of urine. It is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction or neurological conditions affecting bladder function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is diagnosed when an individual experiences leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining or coughing, due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter.

questions.text: From which structure do the alae of the nose develop? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral nasal process

 

Explanation:

 

The development of the face involves five processes: the frontonasal process, medial nasal processes, lateral nasal processes, maxillary processes, and mandibular processes.

 

The central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, develops from the midline frontonasal process. As the nasal pits develop, they give rise to the medial and lateral nasal processes on each side.

 

The alae of the nose, which are the lateral flaring parts of the nostrils, develop from the lateral nasal processes.

 

The maxillary processes give rise to the maxillae, while the mandibular processes form the mandible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontonasal process: Incorrect. The frontonasal process gives rise to the central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, but not the alae.

 

Option B. Medial nasal process: Incorrect. The medial nasal processes contribute to the formation of the median part of the nose, but not the alae.

 

Option D. Bucconasal membrane: Incorrect. The bucconasal membrane is not one of the five processes involved in facial development and does not give rise to the alae of the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The alae of the nose develop from the lateral nasal processes during facial development.

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic patient had undergone surgery for cataract.  6 weeks post-operatively, the patient came with inflammation, decreased vision. On further examination, honeycomb appearance of retina is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

 

The postoperative period, presence of inflammation, decreased vision, and the characteristic honeycomb appearance of the retina are indicative of CME.

 

When CME develops following cataract surgery and its cause is thought to be directly related to the surgery, it is referred to as Irvine-Gass syndrome or pseudophakic CME.

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) involves fluid accumulation within the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to swelling and cyst-like spaces, which can create a honeycomb appearance on optical coherence tomography (OCT). CME is a common complication after cataract surgery, particularly in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR (Central Serous Retinopathy): Central serous retinopathy is characterized by the accumulation of fluid under the retina, which can cause visual disturbances. It often presents with a serous detachment of the central retina. The classic appearance is not honeycomb-like, and CSR is typically not associated with inflammation.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is a serious condition where the retina peels away from its underlying layer of support tissue. The classic symptoms are the sudden appearance of floaters, flashes, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. The honeycomb pattern is not characteristic of retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the retina. It typically presents with dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and neovascularization. While macular edema can occur in diabetic retinopathy, the description of a postoperative honeycomb appearance of the retina is more specific to cystoid macular edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with postoperative inflammation and decreased vision featuring a honeycomb appearance of the retina, the likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with chronic heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide


Loop diuretics like furosemide do not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure.

 

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

 

  • Beta blockers
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists like spironolactone and epleronone
  • Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) like valsartan plus sacubitril
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors like empagliflozin

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The marked landmark corresponds to which structure?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Marked landmark corresponds to ulnar nerve

 

Arrow points toward the medial epicondyle and Ulnar nerve passes below it.

 

The ulnar nerve gives no branches in the arm. It runs distally through the axilla medial to the axillary artery and between it and the vein, continuing distally medial to the brachial artery as far as the midarm. Here it pierces the medial intermuscular septum, inclining medially as it descends anterior to the medial head of triceps to the interval between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon, with the superior ulnar collateral artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve enters the arm lateral to the brachial artery. Near the insertion of coracobrachialis it crosses in front of the artery, descending medial to it to the cubital fossa where it is posterior to the bicipital aponeurosis and anterior to brachialis, separated by the latter from the elbow joint.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: supplies the long head of triceps, and gives rise to the posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm which supplies the skin along the posterior surface of the upper arm. It then spirals obliquely across the back of the humerus, lying posterior to the uppermost fibres of the medial head of triceps which separate the nerve from the bone in the first part of the spiral groove. On reaching the lateral side of the humerus it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum to enter the anterior compartment; it then descends deep in a furrow between brachialis and proximally brachioradialis, then more distally extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the anterior rami (branches) of the spinal nerves C5, C6, and C7. After its origin, the musculocutaneous nerve courses downward through the axilla (armpit) alongside the axillary artery. It then enters the anterior compartment of the arm by piercing through the coracobrachialis muscle. It provide motor innervation to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. These muscles include coracobrachialis and biceps brachii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

 

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a â€˜discrete probability distributionâ€™ that expresses the â€˜probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of timeâ€™ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poissonâ€™s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution and Option D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides â€“ â€˜bell shaped distributionâ€™.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 80 hours

 

To determine how long it will take for the patient's serum digoxin concentration to decrease to a therapeutic level (1 mg/dL) from 4 mg/dL, we need to consider the drug's half-life. The half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, which means that every 40 hours, the concentration of the drug in the plasma will be reduced by half.

 

  • Initial concentration: 4 mg/dL
  • Therapeutic concentration: 1 mg/dL
  • Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours

 

We can use the concept of half-lives to calculate the time needed:

 

  1. After the first half-life (40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 4 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.
  2. After the second half-life (another 40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 2 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL.

 

Therefore, it will take 80 hours for the digoxin concentration to fall from 4 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL, which is within the therapeutic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient experiencing side effects from digoxin with a serum concentration of 4 mg/dL, wait 80 hours (two half-lives) for the concentration to decrease to the therapeutic range before resuming treatment.

questions.text: A truck driver is presenting with a painless ulcer with firm base, what is the next investigation you will prefer to do?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscopy for spirochetes

 

The presentation of a painless ulcer with a firm base is highly suggestive of a syphilitic chancre, which is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The most appropriate next investigation for diagnosing syphilis in this context is dark field microscopy.

 

 

Dark Field Microscopy:

 

  • It is used to directly visualize Treponema pallidum in fluid from the ulcer.
  • This method allows the detection of the characteristic motility of spirochetes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gram staining: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum is not effectively visualized with Gram staining due to its thin and delicate structure.

 

Option C. Tzanck smear for giant cells: Incorrect. Tzanck smear is used for diagnosing viral infections like herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which present with different clinical features such as painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Cell line culture: Incorrect. Cell culture is not routinely used for diagnosing syphilis and is more applicable for viral pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An adult male patient presented with the following condition on his private parts. A gram-negative diplococci was found in the gram stain. The drug of choice for treatment is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tab Cefixime 400 mg

 

The patient presents with discharge from the penis, and the gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci. This is characteristic of an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common sexually transmitted infection that causes urethritis in males, characterized by purulent discharge and dysuria. The drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae is Cefixime 400 mg, which is effective against this bacterium due to its broad-spectrum activity against gram-negative organisms, including Neisseria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tab Azithromycin: Azithromycin is often used in combination therapy for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, but it is not the primary treatment for Neisseria gonorrhoeae alone.

 

Option C. Tab Doxycycline 200 mg: Doxycycline is used primarily for chlamydial infections and is not the drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Inj. Benzathine Penicillin: Penicillin is used for treating syphilis, another sexually transmitted infection, but it is not effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae due to the development of resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, characterized by gram-negative diplococci and purulent discharge, the recommended treatment is Cefixime 400 mg.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Choledochal cyst

 

The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image shows a fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct (CBD), which is characteristic of a choledochal cyst, specifically Type 1. Type 1 choledochal cysts are the most common type and are characterized by this distinctive fusiform dilatation of the CBD. Choledochal cysts are congenital anomalies of the bile duct that can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, or pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: This is a malignant tumor of the bile ducts that typically appears as a mass, often associated with bile duct obstruction. The classic presentation on imaging is a mass lesion, often seen at the perihilar (Klatskin tumor) or distal bile ducts, which is not observed in the provided image.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This rare congenital disorder involves the dilation of intrahepatic bile ducts, not extrahepatic ones like the CBD. A key imaging feature of Caroli disease is the "central dot sign," where dilated bile ducts contain a small dot representing a portal vein radical, which is absent in this image.

 

Option D. Choledocholithiasis: This condition involves the presence of stones within the bile ducts, which appear as signal voids on MRCP. The provided image does not show such signal voids, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct on MRCP is characteristic of a Type 1 choledochal cyst, the most common type of choledochal cyst.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

 

The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucherâ€™s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme Î²-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of Glucose 6 phosphatase is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD-I) or von Gierke disease. This disorder primarily affects glucose metabolism and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option D. Beta-Galactosidase: Deficiency of Beta-Galactosidase is associated with GM1 gangliosidosis. This lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects the nervous system and is not typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 235

choices.text: Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing
Telomerase is found in somatic cells

questions.text: True about telomeres and telomerase is:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing

 

This statement is correct. Telomeres naturally shorten with each cell division, and this gradual shortening is associated with the aging process. It's a result of the end replication problem, where the DNA replication machinery cannot fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomere length with ageing: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging. Over time, this can contribute to cellular senescence and aging.

 

Option C. Telomeres have coding sequences: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres do not contain coding sequences for proteins. Instead, they consist of repetitive DNA sequences that provide a buffer zone to protect the essential genetic information during cell division.

 

Option D. Telomerase is found in somatic cells: This statement is generally incorrect. Telomerase, the enzyme that can counteract telomere shortening by adding repetitive DNA sequences, is typically more active in germ cells and certain stem cells. In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is low, contributing to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomeres are end of chromosomes and do not contain any coding sequences. Instead it has TTAGGG sequence repeated â€˜nâ€™ no. of times.

 

Telomerase is enzyme present only in the germ/stem cells and is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres due to its RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity.

 

In Somatic cells, absence of telomerase enzyme (option d is false) results in telomere shortening as the cells ages.

 

Reference: Harperâ€™s 31st ed/pg- 355, 716
